docs.text:
Home


Welcome to Atlas' Documentation. The aim here is to help you learn how to use Atlas, give you tips and make everything super simple for you to follow.


If you're new to using Atlas, you will probably want to check out the 
quick start
 guide.




Note


These docs are still a work in progress, please excuse the mess!




Features




99% Uptime 24/7


Moderation commands


Clear music


Fast support


Levels


Welcome and Leave messages


Custom commands




Support Server


If you're still puzzled and want help, please join our support server below.


Keep in mind that unfortunately, we're still humans and won't be able to get to you instantly - that said, we'll try our best.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Welcome to Atlas' Documentation. The aim here is to help you learn how to use Atlas, give you tips and make everything super simple for you to follow.  If you're new to using Atlas, you will probably want to check out the  quick start  guide.   Note  These docs are still a work in progress, please excuse the mess!
docs.title: Home

docs.text: 99% Uptime 24/7  Moderation commands  Clear music  Fast support  Levels  Welcome and Leave messages  Custom commands
docs.title: Features

docs.title: Support Server

docs.text:
Quick Start


Get Atlas up and running in a few super simple steps.


Inviting Atlas


Before you can use Atlas, it must be invited to your server. Click 
here
 to go to Discord's authentication page. Select your server from the dropdown, then click Authorize. Atlas should show up as a member in your server, meaning you've successfully invited Atlas.




Note


If your server doesn't show up in the dropdown, ensure you have administrator permissions in the server you want Atlas in.




Running Commands


Atlas is controlled primarily by commands. To run a command, do 
a!<command name>
. For example, to list all commands, type a message that says 
a!help
 and Atlas will direct-message you a list of commands.


Configuring Atlas


To configure Atlas, you'll probably want to use the dashboard. It's super simple and easy to use, and far better than commands.




Go 
here


Login to your Discord account if needed and click 
Authorize


Don't worry, Atlas won't be able to modify your account or use it in any way, this just allows us to verify who you are and see what guilds you share with Atlas.






Once logged in, go to the top right and click "Servers", select your server from the list.




That's it! Once you're there, you can go into various modules and modify them however you'd like.
docs.title: Quick Start

docs.text: Get Atlas up and running in a few super simple steps.
docs.title: Quick Start

docs.text: Before you can use Atlas, it must be invited to your server. Click  here  to go to Discord's authentication page. Select your server from the dropdown, then click Authorize. Atlas should show up as a member in your server, meaning you've successfully invited Atlas.   Note  If your server doesn't show up in the dropdown, ensure you have administrator permissions in the server you want Atlas in.
docs.title: Inviting Atlas

docs.text: Atlas is controlled primarily by commands. To run a command, do  a!<command name> . For example, to list all commands, type a message that says  a!help  and Atlas will direct-message you a list of commands.
docs.title: Running Commands

docs.text: To configure Atlas, you'll probably want to use the dashboard. It's super simple and easy to use, and far better than commands.   Go  here  Login to your Discord account if needed and click  Authorize  Don't worry, Atlas won't be able to modify your account or use it in any way, this just allows us to verify who you are and see what guilds you share with Atlas.    Once logged in, go to the top right and click "Servers", select your server from the list.   That's it! Once you're there, you can go into various modules and modify them however you'd like.
docs.title: Configuring Atlas

docs.text:
Custom Commands


Custom commands are a powerful feature that Atlas has allowing you to create your own commands. You can create custom commands to explain things to users without having to type multiple paragraphs every time someone asks or copy/paste the response. You could also use them in many other creative ways, like force users to agree to a TOS by using the {addrole} variable which gives them a role with more permissions, then restrict access to only the agree channel when they join.


Creating Commands


Before creating your own commands, you'll have to go to your servers dashboard. Go 
here
 and sign in, then select your server from the dropdown at the top right. Go to the Custom Commands module on your right. This is where you can control commands by creating, modifying, deleting or disabling them.


After that, you can click the 
New Command
 button which will bring up a modal showing you options for your new command. Commands must have a name and response, everything else is optional. Command names cannot have spaces, so keep that in mind.


Variables


You can create dynamic custom commands using variables. Variables are like placeholders for data that Atlas will fill in, though that isn't all they can do.


You can see most variables on your left under "Variables".
docs.title: Custom Commands

docs.text: Custom commands are a powerful feature that Atlas has allowing you to create your own commands. You can create custom commands to explain things to users without having to type multiple paragraphs every time someone asks or copy/paste the response. You could also use them in many other creative ways, like force users to agree to a TOS by using the {addrole} variable which gives them a role with more permissions, then restrict access to only the agree channel when they join.
docs.title: Custom Commands

docs.text: Before creating your own commands, you'll have to go to your servers dashboard. Go  here  and sign in, then select your server from the dropdown at the top right. Go to the Custom Commands module on your right. This is where you can control commands by creating, modifying, deleting or disabling them.  After that, you can click the  New Command  button which will bring up a modal showing you options for your new command. Commands must have a name and response, everything else is optional. Command names cannot have spaces, so keep that in mind.
docs.title: Creating Commands

docs.title: Variables

docs.text:
Join and Leave Messages


These are messages that are sent when a user joins or leaves the server. You can customise them to your liking via the 
dashboard
.
docs.title: Join and Leave Messages

docs.text: These are messages that are sent when a user joins or leaves the server. You can customise them to your liking via the  dashboard .
docs.title: Join and Leave Messages

docs.text:
Levels


With this module, server members are able to gain levels and rewards by interacting with the server. When a user levels up, they'll get a small customisable announcement that supports variables.
docs.title: Levels

docs.text: With this module, server members are able to gain levels and rewards by interacting with the server. When a user levels up, they'll get a small customisable announcement that supports variables.
docs.title: Levels

docs.text:
args [index, range]


Gets the arguments provided when executing the command.


Example




Note


For this example, let's assume the command name was 
command
 and it was run like this

a!command this is definitely not a test




Input


{args}
{args;2}
{args;2;2}




Output


this is definitely not a test
is
is definitely




Supports




Custom commands

docs.text: Gets the arguments provided when executing the command.

docs.text:
giverole [role]


Give a user a role from the server. 
Be careful with this variable
 as it utilizes Atlas' famously terrible fuzzy searching, meaning if you enter a role name that is then deleted, Atlas will try and find another role that matches it. E.g, 
if you have a role named "Ad"
 which for whatever reason you want to give to a user, and it is deleted, 
then you have another role with administrator permissions called "Administrator"
, 
when that "Ad" is deleted Atlas will find the closest match, which would be Administrator
. It's a worst case scenario and may be changed in the future, but for now just be really, really careful.


Example


Input


{giverole;Humans} You've been added to the Humans role.




Output


You've been added to the Humans role.






Note


This would give the user the "Humans" role, then return nothing and say the sentence.




Supports




Custom commands


Join messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: giverole [role]

docs.text: Give a user a role from the server.  Be careful with this variable  as it utilizes Atlas' famously terrible fuzzy searching, meaning if you enter a role name that is then deleted, Atlas will try and find another role that matches it. E.g,  if you have a role named "Ad"  which for whatever reason you want to give to a user, and it is deleted,  then you have another role with administrator permissions called "Administrator" ,  when that "Ad" is deleted Atlas will find the closest match, which would be Administrator . It's a worst case scenario and may be changed in the future, but for now just be really, really careful.
docs.title: giverole [role]

docs.text: Input  {giverole;Humans} You've been added to the Humans role.  Output  You've been added to the Humans role.   Note  This would give the user the "Humans" role, then return nothing and say the sentence.
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

docs.text:
randstr [chars, length]


Returns a random string of characters.


Example


Input


{randstr;qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnmQWERTYUIOPASDFGHJKLZXCVBNM_-.;{range;55;60}}




Output


Je-ACKgLOFxfZ.GaOLSvGygUCdbaIhOthbOHNNgmna-mr-MdPAiprXasLpyEqxGlPpj-VcKYHyeDFeVltVLz






Note


This will return a random string of characters using the words as the possible characters and the length as the length of the randomised string. 
{range;55;60}
 will return a value between 55 and 60.




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: randstr [chars, length]

docs.text: Returns a random string of characters.

docs.title: Example

docs.text:
removerole [role]


Remove a users role. This uses a fuzzy matching algorithm, so be careful not to remove roles you don't want by deleting the target role.


Example


Input


{removerole;Humans} You've been removed from the Humans role.




Output


You've been removed from the Humans role






Note


This would remove the "Humans" role from the user, then return nothing and say the sentence.




Supports




Custom commands


Join messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: removerole [role]

docs.text: Remove a users role. This uses a fuzzy matching algorithm, so be careful not to remove roles you don't want by deleting the target role.
docs.title: removerole [role]

docs.text: Input  {removerole;Humans} You've been removed from the Humans role.  Output  You've been removed from the Humans role   Note  This would remove the "Humans" role from the user, then return nothing and say the sentence.
docs.title: Example

docs.text:
set [key] [value]


Set a variable to be used later. This is not persistent 
yet
, so if you run a command that sets X to something, and another that gets X, the second one won't know what you're talking about.


You may also be interested in 
get


Example


Input


{set;x;oof}
{get;x}




Output


oof




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages

docs.title: set [key] [value]

docs.text:
Input  {set;x;oof}
{get;x}  Output  oof
docs.title: Example

docs.text:
guild.ownerID


Returns the guild's owner's ID, which looks something like 
111372124383428608


Example


Input


The owner of this server is <@{guild.ownerID}>




Output


The owner of this server is @Sylver






Note


<@111372124383428608>
 would mention a user (in that case, 
Sylver#1058
), so 
<@{guild.ownerID}>
 will mention the guild owner.




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: guild.ownerID

docs.text: Returns the guild's owner's ID, which looks something like  111372124383428608
docs.title: guild.ownerID

docs.text: Input  The owner of this server is <@{guild.ownerID}>  Output  The owner of this server is @Sylver   Note  <@111372124383428608>  would mention a user (in that case,  Sylver#1058 ), so  <@{guild.ownerID}>  will mention the guild owner.
docs.title: Example

docs.text:
mention.channel [channel]


Mentions a channel. Uses fuzzy matching to find it based on what you input.




Note


Atlas will try and pick up regular user, channel and role mentions, so you shouldn't ever have to use this variable. Just tag whatever you're after regularly, for example 
#channelname
 and Atlas will convert it to a channel mention.




Example


Input


{mention.channel;general}




Output


#general




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: mention.channel [channel]

docs.text: Mentions a channel. Uses fuzzy matching to find it based on what you input.   Note  Atlas will try and pick up regular user, channel and role mentions, so you shouldn't ever have to use this variable. Just tag whatever you're after regularly, for example  #channelname  and Atlas will convert it to a channel mention.
docs.title: mention.channel [channel]

docs.text: Input  {mention.channel;general}  Output  #general
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join and leave messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

docs.text:
mention.user [user]


Mentions a user. 
user
 can be a id, nickname or username. This searches for members in the guild, so for leave messages this won't be a great idea.


If no user is provided, it will fall back to whoever called the command, levelled up or joined.




Note


Atlas will try and pick up regular user, channel and role mentions, so you shouldn't ever have to use this variable. Just tag whatever you're after regularly, for example 
#channelname
 and Atlas will convert it to a channel mention.




Example


Input


{mention.user;Sylver}




Output


@Sylver#1058




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: mention.user [user]

docs.text: Mentions a user.  user  can be a id, nickname or username. This searches for members in the guild, so for leave messages this won't be a great idea.  If no user is provided, it will fall back to whoever called the command, levelled up or joined.   Note  Atlas will try and pick up regular user, channel and role mentions, so you shouldn't ever have to use this variable. Just tag whatever you're after regularly, for example  #channelname  and Atlas will convert it to a channel mention.
docs.title: mention.user [user]

docs.text: Input  {mention.user;Sylver}  Output  @Sylver#1058
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join and leave messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

docs.text:
delete


Delete the original message that caused the... "thing". For custom commands, this deletes the invocation message, for level up messages it deletes the message that caused the level-up.


Example


Input


{delete} *boop*




Output


*boop*






Note


This would have deleted the message that called it, but of course you can't see that here.




Supports




Custom commands


Level-up messages
docs.title: delete

docs.text: Delete the original message that caused the... "thing". For custom commands, this deletes the invocation message, for level up messages it deletes the message that caused the level-up.
docs.title: delete

docs.text: Input  {delete} *boop*  Output  *boop*   Note  This would have deleted the message that called it, but of course you can't see that here.
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

semi


Returns a semicolon, useful if the compiler keeps eating them up or you want one in the middle of a variable.


Example


Input


{semi}




Output


;




Supports

docs.text:
user.avatarURL


Returns the users avatar URL.


Example


Input


Your avatar is {user.avatarURL}!




Output


Your avatar is <really long url>!




Supports

Join messages

docs.text:
user.discriminator


Returns the users discriminator. The discriminator is that number after your name, for example if your full tag was 
Sylver#1058
, your discriminator is 
1058
.


Example


Input


Hello {user.username}#{user.discriminator}!




Output


Hello Sylver#1058!




Supports




Custom commands


Join messages


Level-up messages

docs.text: Returns the users discriminator. The discriminator is that number after your name, for example if your full tag was  Sylver#1058 , your discriminator is  1058 .
docs.title: user.discriminator

docs.text: Input  Hello {user.username}#{user.discriminator}!  Output  Hello Sylver#1058!
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

docs.text:
user.level


Returns the users level. Currently only available in level-up messages.


Example


Input


Congratulations! You've leveled up to level {user.level}!




Output


Congratulations! You've leveled up to level 1!




Supports




Level-up messages

docs.text:
user.mention


Returns a mention for the user. This is not fully supported for leave messages yet, though it should work most of the time.


Example


Input


Hello {user.mention}!




Output


Hello @Sylver!




Supports




Custom commands


Join messages


Level-up messages

docs.text:
user.nickname


Returns the user's nickname, if they don't have one it will fall back to their username.


Example


Input


Hello {user.nickname}!




Output


Hello definitely_not_sylver!






Note


This assumes the user has a nickname in the guild that is 
definitely_not_sylver
 while their real username is 
Sylver




Supports




Custom commands


Join messages


Level-up messages

docs.text: Returns the user's nickname, if they don't have one it will fall back to their username.

docs.text: Input  Hello {user.nickname}!  Output  Hello definitely_not_sylver!   Note  This assumes the user has a nickname in the guild that is  definitely_not_sylver  while their real username is  Sylver
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

Returns the users tag, their username and discriminator combined with a hashtag, for example 
Sylver#1058
.


Example


Input


Hello {user.tag}!




Output


Hello Sylver#1058!




Supports




Custom commands


Join messages


Level-up messages
